expp.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

expsi.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
expsi.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

fAnthDisturb.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fAnthDisturb.long_name: Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation, Litter or Soil Pools into the Atmosphere due to Any Human Activity
fAnthDisturb.comment: will require some careful definition to make sure we capture everything - any human activity that releases carbon to the atmosphere instead of into product pool goes here. E.g. Deforestation fire, harvest assumed to decompose straight away, grazing...

fBNF.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fBNF.comment: The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. On land, 'nitrogen fixation' means the uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere. The representation of fixed nitrogen is model dependent, with the nitrogen entering either vegetation, soil or both. 'Vegetation' means any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. 'Nitrogen compounds' summarizes all chemical species containing nitrogen atoms. The list of individual species that are included in this quantity can vary between models. Where possible, the data variable should be accompanied by a complete description of the species represented, for example, by using a comment attribute.

fCLandToOcean.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fCLandToOcean.long_name: Lateral transfer of carbon out of gridcell that eventually goes into ocean
fCLandToOcean.comment: leached carbon etc that goes into run off or river routing and finds its way into ocean should be reported here.

fDeforestToAtmos.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fDeforestToAtmos.long_name: Deforested biomass that goes into atmosphere as a result of anthropogenic land use change
fDeforestToAtmos.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

fDeforestToProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fDeforestToProduct.long_name: Deforested biomass that goes into product pool as a result of anthropogenic land use change
fDeforestToProduct.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

fFireAll.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fFireAll.long_name: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere due to CO2 emissions from Fire resulting from all sources including natural, anthropogenic and land use change.
fFireAll.comment: Only total fire emissions can be compared to observations.

fFireNat.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fFireNat.long_name: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere due to CO2 Emission from natural Fire

fHarvestToAtmos.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fHarvestToAtmos.long_name: Harvested biomass that goes straight into atmosphere
fHarvestToAtmos.comment: any harvested carbon that is assumed to decompose immediately into the atmosphere is reported here

fHarvestToProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fHarvestToProduct.long_name: Harvested biomass that goes into product pool
fHarvestToProduct.comment: be it food or wood harvest, any carbon that is subsequently stored is reported here

fLitterFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fLitterFire.long_name: Carbon Mass Flux from Litter, CWD or any non-living pool into Atmosphere due to CO2 Emission from all Fire
fLitterFire.comment: Required for unambiguous separation of vegetation and soil + litter turnover times, since total fire flux draws from both sources

fLuc.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fLuc.long_name: Net Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere due to Land Use Change
fLuc.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to human changes to land (excluding forest regrowth) accounting possibly for different time-scales related to fate of the wood, for example.

fLulccAtmLut.long_name: carbon transferred directly to atmosphere due to any land-use or land-cover change activities including deforestation or agricultural fire
fLulccAtmLut.comment: This annual mean flux refers to the transfer of carbon directly to the atmosphere due to any land-use or land-cover change activities.  Include carbon transferred due to deforestation or agricultural directly into atmosphere, and  emissions form anthropogenic pools into atmosphere

fLulccProductLut.long_name: carbon harvested due to land-use or land-cover change process that enters anthropogenic product pools on tile
fLulccProductLut.comment: This annual mean flux refers to the transfer of carbon primarily through harvesting land use into anthropogenic product pools, e.g.,deforestation or wood harvestingfrom primary or secondary lands, food harvesting on croplands, harvesting (grazing) by animals on pastures.

fLulccResidueLut.long_name: carbon transferred to soil or litter pools due to land-use or land-cover change processes on tile
fLulccResidueLut.comment: This annual mean flux refers to the transfer of carbon into soil or litter pools due to any land use or land-cover change activities

fN2O.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

fNAnthDisturb.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNAnthDisturb.long_name: nitrogen mass flux out of land due to any human activity
fNAnthDisturb.comment: will require some careful definition to make sure we capture everything - any human activity that releases nitrogen from land  instead of into product pool goes here. E.g. Deforestation fire, harvest assumed to decompose straight away, grazing...

fNLandToOcean.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNLandToOcean.long_name: Lateral transfer of nitrogen out of gridcell that eventually goes into ocean
fNLandToOcean.comment: leached nitrogen etc that goes into run off or river routing and finds its way into ocean should be reported here.

fNLitterSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNLitterSoil.long_name: Total Nitrogen Mass Flux from Litter to Soil
fNLitterSoil.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil.

fNOx.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNOx.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. 'Nox' means a combination of two radical species containing nitrogen and oxygen NO+NO2. 'Vegetation' means any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil.

fNProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNProduct.long_name: Deforested or harvested biomass as a result of anthropogenic land use or change
fNProduct.comment: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

fNVegLitter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNVegLitter.long_name: Total Nitrogen Mass Flux from Vegetation to Litter
fNVegLitter.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. 'Vegetation' means any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass.

fNVegSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNVegSoil.long_name: Total Nitrogen Mass Flux from Vegetation Directly to Soil
fNVegSoil.comment: In some models part of nitrogen (e.g., root exudate) can go directly into the soil pool without entering litter.

fNdep.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNdep.long_name: Dry and Wet Deposition of Reactive Nitrogen onto Land
fNdep.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The 'atmosphere content' of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface to the top of the atmosphere. For the content between specified levels in the atmosphere, standard names including 'content_of_atmosphere_layer' are used. 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. 'Deposition' is the sum of wet and dry deposition. 'Nitrogen compounds' summarizes all chemical species containing nitrogen atoms.

fNfert.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNfert.long_name: total N added for cropland fertilisation (artificial and manure)
fNfert.comment: relative to total land area of a grid cell, not relative to agricultural area

fNgas.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNgas.long_name: Total Nitrogen lost to the atmosphere (sum of NHx, NOx, N2O, N2)

fNgasFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNgasFire.long_name: Total N lost to the atmosphere (including NHx, NOx, N2O, N2) from fire.
fNgasFire.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. 'Nitrogen compounds' summarizes all chemical species containing nitrogen atoms. The list of individual species that are included in this quantity can vary between models. Where possible, the data variable should be accompanied by a complete description of the species represented, for example, by using a comment attribute.

fNgasNonFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNgasNonFire.long_name: Total N lost to the atmosphere (including NHx, NOx, N2O, N2) from all processes except fire.
fNgasNonFire.comment: 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. 'Nitrogen compounds' summarizes all chemical species containing nitrogen atoms. The list of individual species that are included in this quantity can vary between models. Where possible, the data variable should be accompanied by a complete description of the species represented, for example, by using a comment attribute.

fNleach.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNleach.long_name: Total N loss to leaching or runoff (sum of ammonium, nitrite and nitrate)
fNleach.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. 'Leaching' means the loss of water soluble chemical species from soil. Runoff is the liquid water which drains from land. If not specified, 'runoff' refers to the sum of surface runoff and subsurface drainage.

fNloss.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNloss.long_name: Total N lost (including NHx, NOx, N2O, N2 and leaching)
fNloss.comment: Not all models split losses into gasesous and leaching

fNnetmin.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNnetmin.long_name: Net nitrogen release from soil and litter as the outcome of nitrogen immobilisation and gross mineralisation

fNup.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fNup.long_name: total plant nitrogen uptake (sum of ammonium and nitrate), irrespective of the source of nitrogen

fProductDecomp.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fProductDecomp.long_name: decomposition out of product pools to CO2 in atmos
fProductDecomp.comment: 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. The chemical formula for carbon dioxide is CO2. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The 'atmosphere content' of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface to the top of the atmosphere. For the content between specified levels in the atmosphere, standard names including 'content_of_atmosphere_layer' are used. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. 'Emission' means emission from a primary source located anywhere within the atmosphere, including at the lower boundary (i.e.

fProductDecompLut.long_name: flux from wood and agricultural product pools on land use tile into atmosphere
fProductDecompLut.comment: If  a model has explicit anthropogenic product pools by land use tile

fVegFire.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegFire.long_name: Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation into Atmosphere due to CO2 Emission from all Fire
fVegFire.comment: Required for unambiguous separation of vegetation and soil + litter turnover times, since total fire flux draws from both sources

fVegLitterMortality.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegLitterMortality.long_name: Total Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation to Litter as a Result of Mortality
fVegLitterMortality.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fVegLitterSenescence.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegLitterSenescence.long_name: Total Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation to Litter as a Result of Leaf, Branch, and Root Senescence
fVegLitterSenescence.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fVegSoilMortality.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegSoilMortality.long_name: Total Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation to Soil as a result of mortality
fVegSoilMortality.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fVegSoilSenescence.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
fVegSoilSenescence.long_name: Total Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation to Soil as a result of leaf, branch, and root senescence
fVegSoilSenescence.comment: needed to separate changing vegetation C turnover times resulting from changing allocation versus changing mortality

fahLut.long_name: Anthropogenic heat flux generated from non-renewable human primary energy consumption, including energy use by vehicles, commercial and residential buildings, industry, and power plants.  Primary energy refers to energy in natural resources, fossil and nonfossil, before conversion into other forms, such as electricity.
fahLut.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The vertical heat flux in air is the sum of all heat fluxes i.e. radiative, latent and sensible. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. 'Anthropogenic' means influenced, caused, or created by human activity. The heat flux due to anthropogenic energy consumption results from non-renewable human primary energy consumption, including energy use by vehicles, commercial and residential buildings, industry, and power plants. Primary energy refers to energy in natural resources, fossil and non-fossil, before conversion into other forms, such as electricity.

fddtalk.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
fddtalk.long_name: Rate of Change of Total Alkalinity
fddtalk.comment: vertical integral of net time rate of change of alkalinity

fg14co2.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

fg14co2abio.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
fg14co2abio.comment: Gas exchange flux of abiotic 14CO2 (positive into ocean)

fgco2abio.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
fgco2abio.long_name: Surface Downward Flux of Abiotic CO2
fgco2abio.comment: Gas exchange flux of abiotic CO2 (positive into ocean)

fgco2nat.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
fgco2nat.long_name: Surface Downward Flux of Natural CO2
fgco2nat.comment: Gas exchange flux of natural CO2 (positive into ocean)

flandice.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
flandice.long_name: Water flux into Sea Water from Land Ice
flandice.comment: Computed as the water flux into the ocean due to land ice (runoff water from surface and base of land ice or melt from base of ice shelf or vertical ice front) into the ocean divided by the area ocean portion of the grid cell

flashrate.comment: proposed name: lightning_flash_rate (units to be interpreted as 'counts km-2 s-1)

fracLut.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
fracLut.long_name: fraction of grid cell for each land use tile
fracLut.comment: end of year values (not annual mean); note that fraction should be reported as fraction of land grid cell (example: frac_lnd = 0.5, frac_ocn = 0.5, frac_crop_lnd = 0.2 (of land portion of grid cell), then frac_lut(crop) = 0.5*0.2 = 0.1)

gppGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
gppGrass.long_name: gross primary production on grass tiles
gppGrass.comment: Total GPP of grass in the gridcell

gppLut.long_name: gross primary productivity on land use tile
gppLut.comment: 'Production of carbon' means the production of biomass expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. Gross primary production is the rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ('producers'), for example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is 'net_primary_production'. 'Productivity' means production per unit area. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A.

gppShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
gppShrub.long_name: gross primary production on Shrub tiles
gppShrub.comment: Total GPP of shrubs in the gridcell

gppTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
gppTree.long_name: gross primary production on tree tiles
gppTree.comment: Total GPP of trees in the gridcell

gppc13.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
gppc13.long_name: Mass Flux of 13C out of Atmosphere due to Gross Primary Production on Land

gppc14.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
gppc14.long_name: Mass Flux of 14C out of Atmosphere due to Gross Primary Production on Land

grassFracC3.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
grassFracC3.comment: Fraction of entire grid cell covered by C3 grass.

grassFracC4.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
grassFracC4.comment: Fraction of entire grid cell covered by C4 grass.

hcont300.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

hflsLut.long_name: latent heat flux on land use tile
hflsLut.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface latent heat flux is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air on account of evaporation (including sublimation). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

hfssLut.long_name: sensible heat flux on land use tile
hfssLut.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface sensible heat flux, also called 'turbulent' heat flux, is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air by motion of air. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. Unless indicated in the cell_methods attribute, a quantity is assumed to apply to the whole area of each horizontal grid box. Previously, the qualifier where_type was used to specify that the quantity applies only to the part of the grid box of the named type.  Names containing the where_type qualifier are deprecated and newly created data should use the cell_methods attribute to indicate the horizontal area to which the quantity applies.

hursminCrop.cell_methods: area: mean time: minimum within days time: mean over days
hursminCrop.long_name: Daily Minimum Near-Surface Relative Humidity over Crop Tile
hursminCrop.comment: minimum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) relative humidity (add cell_method attribute 'time: min')

hus.comment: 'specific' means per unit mass. Specific humidity is the mass fraction of water vapor in (moist) air.

hus27.comment: 'specific' means per unit mass. Specific humidity is the mass fraction of water vapor in (moist) air.

hussLut.long_name: near-surface specific humidity on land use tile
hussLut.comment: Normally, the specific humidity should be reported at the 2 meter height

intuadse.long_name: Vertically integrated Eastward dry transport (cp.T +zg).u (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of northward wind by dry static_energy per mass unit)
intuadse.comment: Mass weighted vertical integral of the product of northward wind by dry static energy per unit mass: (cp.T +zg).u

intuaw.long_name: Vertically integrated Eastward moisture transport (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of eastward wind by total water mass per unit mass)

intvadse.long_name: Vertically integrated Northward dry transport (cp.T +zg).v (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of northward wind by dry static_energy per mass unit)

intvaw.long_name: Vertically integrated Northward moisture transport (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of northward wind by total water mass per unit mass)

irrLut.long_name: Irrigation flux including any irrigation for crops, trees, pasture, or urban lawns
irrLut.comment: 'Downward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed downward (negative upward). The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. 'Irrigation' includes water used to sustain crops, trees, pastures and urban lawns.

jpdftaureicemodis.long_name: MODIS Optical Thickness-Particle Size joint  distribution, ice
jpdftaureicemodis.comment: 'Layer' means any layer with upper and lower boundaries that have constant values in some vertical coordinate. There must be a vertical coordinate variable indicating the extent of the layer(s). If the layers are model layers, the vertical coordinate can be model_level_number, but it is recommended to specify a physical coordinate (in a scalar or auxiliary coordinate variable) as well. 'X_area_fraction' means the fraction of horizontal area occupied by X. 'X_area' means the horizontal area occupied by X within the grid cell. Cloud area fraction is also called 'cloud amount' and 'cloud cover'.

jpdftaureliqmodis.long_name: MODIS Optical Thickness-Particle Size joint  distribution, liquid
jpdftaureliqmodis.comment: 'Layer' means any layer with upper and lower boundaries that have constant values in some vertical coordinate. There must be a vertical coordinate variable indicating the extent of the layer(s). If the layers are model layers, the vertical coordinate can be model_level_number, but it is recommended to specify a physical coordinate (in a scalar or auxiliary coordinate variable) as well. 'X_area_fraction' means the fraction of horizontal area occupied by X. 'X_area' means the horizontal area occupied by X within the grid cell. Cloud area fraction is also called 'cloud amount' and 'cloud cover'.

laiLut.long_name: Leaf Area Index on Land Use Tile
laiLut.comment: Note that if tile does not model lai, for example, on the urban tile, then should be reported as missing value

lwsrfasdust.long_name: All-sky Surface Longwave radiative flux due to Dust

lwsrfcsdust.long_name: Clear-sky Surface Longwave radiative flux due to Dust

lwtoaasdust.long_name: all sky lw-rf dust at toa

lwtoacsaer.long_name: clear sky lw-rf aerosols at toa

lwtoacsdust.long_name: Clear-sky TOA Longwave radiative flux due to Dust

mmrno3.comment: Mass fraction is used in the construction mass_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y. It means the ratio of the mass of X to the mass of Y (including X). 'Mass_fraction_of_nitrate' means that the mass is expressed as mass of NO3. 'Aerosol' means the system of suspended liquid or solid particles in air (except cloud droplets) and their carrier gas, the air itself. Aerosol particles take up ambient water (a process known as hygroscopic growth) depending on the relative humidity and the composition of the particles. 'Dry aerosol particles' means aerosol particles without any water uptake.

mrlso.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrlso.comment: The mass (summed over all all layers) of liquid water.

mrroLut.long_name: Total runoff from land use tile
mrroLut.comment: the total runoff (including 'drainage' through the base of the soil model) leaving the land use tile portion of the grid cell

mrsfl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrsfl.long_name: Frozen water content of soil layer
mrsfl.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in ice phase.  Reported as 'missing' for grid cells occupied entirely by 'sea'

mrsll.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrsll.long_name: Liquid water content of soil layer
mrsll.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in liquid phase.  Reported as 'missing' for grid cells occupied entirely by 'sea'

mrsol.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrsol.long_name: Total water content of soil layer
mrsol.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in all phases, including ice.  Reported as 'missing' for grid cells occupied entirely by 'sea'

mrsosLut.long_name: Moisture in Upper Portion of Soil Column of land use tile
mrsosLut.comment: the mass of water in all phases in a thin surface layer; integrate over uppermost 10cm

mrtws.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrtws.long_name: Total water storage in a grid cell
mrtws.comment: Mass of water in all phases and in all components including soil, canopy, vegetation, ice sheets, rivers and ground water.

nLand.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLand.long_name: Total nitrogen in all terrestrial nitrogen pools
nLand.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nLeaf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLeaf.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area.

nLitter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitter.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nLitterCwd.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitterCwd.long_name: Nitrogen Mass in Coarse Woody Debris
nLitterCwd.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Wood debris' means dead organic matter composed of coarse wood. It is distinct from fine litter. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.

nLitterSubSurf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitterSubSurf.long_name: Nitrogen Mass in below ground litter (non CWD)
nLitterSubSurf.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Subsurface litter' means the part of the litter mixed within the soil below the surface. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.

nLitterSurf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nLitterSurf.long_name: Nitrogen Mass in above ground litter (non CWD)
nLitterSurf.comment: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Surface litter' means the part of the litter resting above the soil surface. The sum of the quantities with standard names wood_debris_mass_content_of_nitrogen, surface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_nitrogen is the total nitrogen mass content of dead plant material.

nMineral.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nMineral.comment: SUM of ammonium, nitrite, nitrate, etc over all soil layers

nMineralNH4.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nMineralNH4.comment: SUM of ammonium over all soil layers

nMineralNO3.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nMineralNO3.comment: SUM of nitrate over all soil layers

nOther.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nOther.long_name: Nitrogen mass in vegetation components other than leaves, stem and root

nProduct.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nProduct.long_name: Nitrogen Mass in Products of Land Use Change
nProduct.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nRoot.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

nSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nSoil.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

nStem.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

nVeg.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nVeg.comment: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

necbLut.long_name: net rate of C accumulation (or loss) on land use tile
necbLut.comment: Computed as npp minus heterotrophic respiration minus fire minus C leaching minus harvesting/clearing. Positive rate is into the land, negative rate is from the land.  Do not include fluxes from anthropogenic product pools to atmosphere

nep.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nep.long_name: Net Carbon Mass Flux out of Atmophere due to Net Ecosystem Productivity on Land.
nep.comment: Natural flux of CO2 (expressed as a mass flux of carbon) from the atmosphere to the land calculated as the difference between uptake associated will photosynthesis and the release of CO2 from the sum of plant and soil respiration and fire.  Positive flux is into the land.  emissions from natural fires and human ignition fires as calculated by the fire module of the dynamic vegetation model, but excluding any CO2 flux from fire included in fLuc (CO2 Flux to Atmosphere from Land Use Change).

netAtmosLandC13Flux.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
netAtmosLandC13Flux.long_name: Net Mass Flux of 13C between atmosphere and land (positive into land) as a result of all processes.

netAtmosLandC14Flux.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
netAtmosLandC14Flux.long_name: Net Mass Flux of 14C between atmosphere and land (positive into land) as a result of all processes.

netAtmosLandCO2Flux.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
netAtmosLandCO2Flux.long_name: Net flux of CO2 between atmosphere and land (positive into land) as a result of all processes.
netAtmosLandCO2Flux.comment: This flux should be reproducible by differencing the sum of all carbon pools (cVeg, cLitter, cSoil, and cProducts or equivalently cLand) from one time step to the next, except in the case of lateral transfer of carbon due to harvest, riverine transport of dissolved organic and/or inorganic carbon, or any other process (in which case the lateral_carbon_transfer_over_land term, see below, will be zero data).

nppGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
nppGrass.long_name: net primary production on grass tiles
nppGrass.comment: Total NPP of grass in the gridcell

nppLut.long_name: net primary productivity on land use tile
nppLut.comment: 'Production of carbon' means the production of biomass expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. Net primary production is the excess of gross primary production (rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors) by autotrophs ('producers'), for example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton, over the rate at which the autotrophs themselves respire some of this biomass. 'Productivity' means production per unit area. The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A.

nppOther.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nppOther.long_name: net primary production allcoated to other pools (not leaves stem or roots)

nppShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
nppShrub.long_name: net primary production on Shrub tiles
nppShrub.comment: Total NPP of shrubs in the gridcell

nppStem.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
nppStem.long_name: net primary production allcoated to stem

nppTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
nppTree.long_name: net primary production on tree tiles
nppTree.comment: Total NPP of trees in the gridcell

nwdFracLut.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
nwdFracLut.long_name: fraction of land use tile tile that is non-woody vegetation ( e.g. herbaceous crops)
nwdFracLut.comment: 'Area fraction' means the fraction of horizontal area. To specify which area is quantified by a variable of 'area_fraction', provide a coordinate variable or scalar coordinate variable of 'area_type'. Alternatively, if one is defined, use a more specific standard name of 'X_area_fraction' for the fraction of horizontal area occupied by X.

ocontempdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ocontempdiff.long_name: tendency of sea water conservative temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized dianeutral mixing
ocontempdiff.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized dianeutral mixing. Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.

ocontempmint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ocontempmint.long_name: integral wrt depth of product of sea water density and conservative temperature
ocontempmint.comment: Full column sum of density*cell thickness*conservative temperature. If the model is Boussinesq, then use Boussinesq reference density for the density factor.

ocontemppadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ocontemppadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water conservative temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized eddy advection
ocontemppadvect.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized eddy advection (any form of eddy advection). Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.

ocontemppmdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ocontemppmdiff.long_name: tendency of sea water conservative temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized mesoscale diffusion
ocontemppmdiff.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized mesoscale eddy diffusion. Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.

ocontemppsmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ocontemppsmadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water conservative temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized submesoscale advection
ocontemppsmadvect.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized submesoscale eddy advection. Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.

ocontemprmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ocontemprmadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water conservative temperature expressed as heat content due to residual mean (sum of Eulerian + parameterized) advection
ocontemprmadvect.comment: 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The phrase 'expressed_as_heat_content' means that this quantity is calculated as the specific heat capacity times density of sea water multiplied by the conservative temperature of the sea water in the grid cell. Conservative Temperature is defined as part of the Thermodynamic Equation of Seawater 2010 (TEOS-10) which was adopted in 2010 by the International Oceanographic Commission (IOC). Conservative Temperature is specific potential enthalpy (which has the standard name sea_water_specific_potential_enthalpy) divided by a fixed value of the specific heat capacity of sea water, namely cp_0 = 3991.86795711963 J kg-1 K-1. Conservative Temperature is a more accurate measure of the 'heat content' of sea water, by a factor of one hundred, than is potential temperature. Because of this, it can be regarded as being proportional to the heat content of sea water per unit mass. Reference: www.teos-10.

ocontemptend.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ocontemptend.long_name: tendency of sea water conservative temperature expressed as heat content
ocontemptend.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from all processes. Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.

od550aerso.long_name: Stratospheric Optical depth at 550 nm (all aerosols) 2D-field (here we limit the computation of OD to the stratosphere only)
od550aerso.comment: From tropopause to stratopause as defined by the model

od550so4so.long_name: Stratospheric Optical depth at 550 nm (sulphate only) 2D-field (here we limit the computation of OD to the stratosphere only)

opottempdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
opottempdiff.long_name: tendency of sea water potential temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized dianeutral mixing
opottempdiff.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized dianeutral mixing. Reported only for models that use potential temperature as prognostic field.

opottempmint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
opottempmint.long_name: integral wrt depth of product of sea water density and potential temperature
opottempmint.comment: The phrase 'integral_wrt_X_of_Y' means int Y dX. The data variable should have an axis for X specifying the limits of the integral as bounds. The phrase 'wrt' means 'with respect to'. The phrase 'product_of_X_and_Y' means X*Y. Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. Sea water density is the in-situ density (not the potential density). For Boussinesq models, density is the constant Boussinesq reference density, a quantity which has the standard name reference_sea_water_density_for_boussinesq_approximation. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

opottemppadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
opottemppadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water potential temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized eddy advection
opottemppadvect.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized eddy advection (any form of eddy advection). Reported only for models that use potential temperature as prognostic field.

opottemppmdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
opottemppmdiff.long_name: tendency of sea water potential temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized mesoscale diffusion
opottemppmdiff.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized mesoscale eddy diffusion. Reported only for models that use potential temperature as prognostic field.

opottemppsmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
opottemppsmadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water potential temperature expressed as heat content due to parameterized submesoscale advection
opottemppsmadvect.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized submesoscale eddy advection. Reported only for models that use potential temperature as prognostic field.

opottemprmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
opottemprmadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water potential temperature expressed as heat content due to residual mean advection
opottemprmadvect.comment: The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The phrase 'expressed_as_heat_content' means that this quantity is calculated as the specific heat capacity times density of sea water multiplied by the potential temperature of the sea water in the grid cell. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. The phrase 'residual_mean_advection' refers to the sum of the model's resolved advective transport plus any parameterized advective transport. Parameterized advective transport includes processes such as parameterized mesoscale and submesoscale transport, as well as any other advectively parameterized transport.

opottemptend.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
opottemptend.long_name: tendency of sea water potential temperature expressed as heat content
opottemptend.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from all processes. Reported only for models that use potential temperature as prognostic field.

orog.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. Altitude is the (geometric) height above the geoid, which is the reference geopotential surface. The geoid is similar to mean sea level.

osaltdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
osaltdiff.long_name: tendency of sea water salinity expressed as salt content due to parameterized dianeutral mixing
osaltdiff.comment: Tendency of salt content for a grid cell from parameterized dianeutral mixing.

osaltpadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
osaltpadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water salinity expressed as salt content due to parameterized eddy advection
osaltpadvect.comment: Tendency of salt content for a grid cell from parameterized eddy advection (any form of eddy advection).

osaltpmdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
osaltpmdiff.long_name: tendency of sea water salinity expressed as salt content due to parameterized mesoscale diffusion
osaltpmdiff.comment: Tendency of salt content for a grid cell from parameterized mesoscale eddy diffusion.

osaltpsmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
osaltpsmadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water salinity expressed as salt content due to parameterized submesoscale advection
osaltpsmadvect.comment: Tendency of salt content for a grid cell from parameterized submesoscale eddy advection.

osaltrmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
osaltrmadvect.long_name: tendency of sea water salinity expressed as salt content due to residual mean advection
osaltrmadvect.comment: The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. The phrase 'residual_mean_advection' refers to the sum of the model's resolved advective transport plus any parameterized advective transport. Parameterized advective transport includes processes such as parameterized mesoscale and submesoscale transport, as well as any other advectively parameterized transport. When the parameterized advective transport is represented in the model as a skew-diffusion rather than an advection, then the parameterized skew diffusion should be included in this diagnostic, since the convergence of skew-fluxes are identical (in the continuous formulation) to the convergence of advective fluxes.

osalttend.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
osalttend.long_name: tendency of sea water salinity expressed as salt content
osalttend.comment: Tendency of salt content for a grid cell from all processes.

pabigthetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
pabigthetao.comment: The quantity with standard name sea_water_added_conservative_temperature is a passive tracer in an ocean model whose surface flux does not come from the atmosphere but is imposed externally upon the simulated climate system. The surface flux is expressed as a heat flux and converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were a heat flux being added to conservative temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were conservative temperature. The passive tracer is zero in the control climate of the model. The passive tracer records added heat, as described for the CMIP6 FAFMIP experiment (doi:10.5194/gmd-9-3993-2016), following earlier ideas. Conservative Temperature is defined as part of the Thermodynamic Equation of Seawater 2010 (TEOS-10) which was adopted in 2010 by the International Oceanographic Commission (IOC).

parasolRefl.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
parasolRefl.comment: Simulated reflectance from PARASOL as seen at the top of the atmosphere for 5 solar zenith angles. Valid only over ocean and for one viewing direction (viewing zenith angle of 30 degrees and relative azimuth angle 320 degrees).

pastureFracC3.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
pastureFracC3.comment: Percentage of entire grid cell covered by C3 pasture

pastureFracC4.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
pastureFracC4.comment: Percentage of entire grid cell covered by C4 pasture

pathetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
pathetao.comment: The quantity with standard name sea_water_added_potential_temperature is a passive tracer in an ocean model whose surface flux does not come from the atmosphere but is imposed externally upon the simulated climate system. The surface flux is expressed as a heat flux and converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were a heat flux being added to potential temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were potential temperature. The passive tracer is zero in the control climate of the model. The passive tracer records added heat, as described for the CMIP6 FAFMIP experiment (doi:10.5194/gmd-9-3993-2016), following earlier ideas. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

ppcalc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ppcalc.long_name: Net Primary Mole Productivity of Carbon by Calcareous Phytoplankton
ppcalc.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by the calcite-producing phytoplankton component alone

ppdiat.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ppdiat.long_name: Net Primary Organic Carbon Production by Diatoms
ppdiat.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by the diatom component alone

ppdiaz.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ppdiaz.long_name: Net Primary Mole Productivity of Carbon by Diazotrophs
ppdiaz.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by the diazotrophic phytoplankton component alone

ppmisc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
ppmisc.long_name: Net Primary Organic Carbon Production by Other Phytoplankton
ppmisc.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by other phytoplankton components alone

pppico.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
pppico.long_name: Net Primary Mole Productivity of Carbon by Picophytoplankton
pppico.comment: Primary (organic carbon) production by the picophytoplankton (<2 um) component alone

prCrop.comment: includes both liquid and solid phases

prbigthetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
prbigthetao.comment: The quantity with standard name sea_water_redistributed_conservative_temperature is a passive tracer in an ocean model which is subject to an externally imposed perturbative surface heat flux. The passive tracer is initialised to the conservative temperature in the control climate before the perturbation is imposed. Its surface flux is the heat flux from the atmosphere, not including the imposed perturbation, and is converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were being added to conservative temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were conservative temperature. The passive tracer records redistributed heat, as described for the CMIP6 FAFMIP experiment (doi:10.5194/gmd-9-3993-2016), following earlier ideas. Conservative Temperature is defined as part of the Thermodynamic Equation of Seawater 2010 (TEOS-10) which was adopted in 2010 by the International Oceanographic Commission (IOC).

prhmax.cell_methods: area: mean time: mean within hours time: maximum over hours
prhmax.comment: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

prthetao.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
prthetao.comment: The quantity with standard name sea_water_redistributed_potential_temperature is a passive tracer in an ocean model which is subject to an externally imposed perturbative surface heat flux. The passive tracer is initialised to the potential temperature in the control climate before the perturbation is imposed. Its surface flux is the heat flux from the atmosphere, not including the imposed perturbation, and is converted to a passive tracer increment as if it were being added to potential temperature. The passive tracer is transported within the ocean as if it were potential temperature. The passive tracer records redistributed heat, as described for the CMIP6 FAFMIP experiment (doi:10.5194/gmd-9-3993-2016), following earlier ideas. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

ps.comment: surface pressure (not mean sea-level pressure), 2-D field to calculate the 3-D pressure field from hybrid coordinates

raGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
raGrass.comment: Total RA of grass in the gridcell

raLeaf.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

raLut.long_name: plant respiration on land use tile

raOther.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
raOther.long_name: Total respiration from other pools (not leaves stem or roots)

raRoot.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
raRoot.comment: Total autotrophic respiration from all belowground plant parts.  This has benchmarking value because the sum of Rh and root respiration can be compared to observations of total soil respiration.

raShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
raShrub.comment: Total RA of shrubs in the gridcell

raStem.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

raTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
raTree.comment: Total RA of trees in the gridcell

rac13.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rac13.long_name: Mass Flux of 13C into Atmosphere due to Autotrophic (Plant) Respiration on Land

rac14.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rac14.long_name: Mass Flux of 14C into Atmosphere due to Autotrophic (Plant) Respiration on Land

reffclic.long_name: Hydrometeor Effective Radius of Convective Cloud Ice
reffclic.comment: This is defined as the in-cloud ratio of the third moment over the second moment of the particle size distribution (obtained by considering only the cloudy portion of the grid cell).

reffclis.long_name: Hydrometeor Effective Radius of Stratiform Cloud Ice
reffclis.comment: This is defined as the in-cloud ratio of the third moment over the second moment of the particle size distribution (obtained by considering only the cloudy portion of the grid cell).

reffclwc.long_name: Hydrometeor Effective Radius of Convective Cloud Liquid Water
reffclwc.comment: Droplets are liquid.  The effective radius is defined as the ratio of the third moment over the second moment of the particle size distribution and the time-mean should be calculated, weighting the individual samples by the cloudy fraction of the grid cell.

reffclws.long_name: Hydrometeor Effective Radius of Stratiform Cloud Liquid Water
reffclws.comment: Droplets are liquid.  The effective radius is defined as the ratio of the third moment over the second moment of the particle size distribution and the time-mean should be calculated, weighting the individual samples by the cloudy fraction of the grid cell.

rhGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
rhGrass.comment: Total RH of grass in the gridcell

rhLitter.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhLitter.long_name: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere due to Heterotrophic Respiration from Litter on Land
rhLitter.comment: Needed to calculate litter bulk turnover time. Includes respiration from CWD as well.

rhLut.long_name: soil heterotrophic respiration on land use tile

rhShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
rhShrub.comment: Total RH of shrubs in the gridcell

rhSoil.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhSoil.long_name: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere due to Heterotrophic Respiration from Soil on Land
rhSoil.comment: Needed to calculate soil bulk turnover time

rhTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
rhTree.comment: Total RH of trees in the gridcell

rhc13.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhc13.long_name: Mass Flux of 13C into Atmosphere due to Heterotrophic Respiration on Land

rhc14.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
rhc14.long_name: Mass Flux of 14C into Atmosphere due to Heterotrophic Respiration on Land

rlusLut.long_name: Surface Upwelling Longwave on Land Use Tile
rlusLut.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

rsdoabsorb.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
rsdoabsorb.long_name: net rate of absorption of shortwave energy in ocean layer
rsdoabsorb.comment: 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. 'Layer' means any layer with upper and lower boundaries that have constant values in some vertical coordinate. There must be a vertical coordinate variable indicating the extent of the layer(s). If the layers are model layers, the vertical coordinate can be model_level_number, but it is recommended to specify a physical coordinate (in a scalar or auxiliary coordinate variable) as well. Net absorbed radiation is the difference between absorbed and emitted radiation.

rsdscsdiff.long_name: Surface Diffuse Downwelling Clear Sky Shortwave Radiation
rsdscsdiff.comment: Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'.  In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. 'Diffuse' radiation is radiation that has been scattered by particles in the atmosphere such as cloud droplets and aerosols. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called  'flux density' in physics. The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. A phrase 'assuming_condition' indicates that the named quantity is the value which would obtain if all aspects of the system were unaltered except for the assumption of the circumstances specified by the condition. 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation.

rsdsdiff.comment: Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'.  'Diffuse' radiation is radiation that has been scattered by particles in the atmosphere such as cloud droplets and aerosols. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'.  In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'.  In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.  The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere.  'shortwave' means shortwave radiation.

rss.comment: Net downward shortwave radiation at the surface

rsusLut.long_name: Surface Upwelling Shortwave  on Land Use Tile
rsusLut.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

sconcdust.comment: mass concentration of dust dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer

sconcso4.comment: mass concentration of sulfate dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer.

sconcss.comment: mass concentration of seasalt dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer

sedustCI.long_name: Sedimentation Flux of dust mode coarse insoluble

sfcWindmax.cell_methods: area: mean time: maximum within days time: mean over days
sfcWindmax.long_name: Mean Daily Maximum Near-Surface Wind Speed
sfcWindmax.comment: Daily maximum near-surface (usually, 10 meters) wind speed.

somint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
somint.long_name: integral wrt depth of product of sea water density and salinity
somint.comment: Full column sum of density*cell thickness*prognostic salinity. If the model is Boussinesq, then use Boussinesq reference density for the density factor.

sweLut.long_name: snow water equivalent on land use tile
sweLut.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'lwe' means liquid water equivalent. 'Amount' means mass per unit area. The construction lwe_thickness_of_X_amount or _content means the vertical extent of a layer of liquid water having the same mass per unit area. Surface amount refers to the amount on the ground, excluding that on the plant or vegetation canopy.

swsrfasdust.long_name: All-sky Surface Shortwave radiative flux due to Dust

swsrfcsdust.long_name: Clear-sky Surface Shortwave radiative flux due to Dust

swtoaasdust.long_name: all sky sw-rf dust at toa

swtoacsdust.long_name: clear sky sw-rf dust at toa

t20d.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
t20d.comment: This quantity, sometimes called the 'isotherm depth', is the depth (if it exists) at which the sea water potential temperature equals some specified value. This value should be specified in a scalar coordinate variable. Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

tSoilPools.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
tSoilPools.long_name: turnover rate of each model soil carbon pool
tSoilPools.comment: defined as 1/(turnover time) for each soil pool. Use the same pools reported under cSoilPools

tasLut.long_name: near-surface air temperature (2m above displacement height, i.e. t_ref) on land use tile
tasLut.comment: Air temperature is the bulk temperature of the air, not the surface (skin) temperature.

tasmaxCrop.cell_methods: area: mean time: maximum within days time: mean over days
tasmaxCrop.long_name: Daily Maximum Near-Surface Air Temperature over Crop Tile
tasmaxCrop.comment: maximum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: max')

tasminCrop.cell_methods: area: mean time: minimum within days time: mean over days
tasminCrop.long_name: Daily Minimum Near-Surface Air Temperature over Crop Tile
tasminCrop.comment: minimum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: min')

tdps.comment: Dew point temperature is the temperature at which a parcel of air reaches saturation upon being cooled at constant pressure and specific humidity.

thetaot.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
thetaot.long_name: Vertically Averaged Sea Water Potential Temperature
thetaot.comment: Vertical average of the sea water potential temperature through the whole ocean depth

thetaot2000.long_name: Depth average potential temperature of upper 2000m

thetaot300.long_name: Depth average potential temperature of upper 300m

thetaot700.long_name: Depth average potential temperature of upper 700m

tnhuspbl.long_name: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Boundary Layer Mixing
tnhuspbl.comment: Includes all boundary layer terms including diffusive terms.

tnhusscp.long_name: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Stratiform Clouds and Precipitation
tnhusscp.comment: The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. 'Specific' means per unit mass. Specific humidity is the mass fraction of water vapor in (moist) air. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. A variable with the standard name of tendency_of_specific_humidity_due_to_stratiform_cloud_and_precipitation should contain the effects of all processes which convert stratiform clouds and precipitation to or from water vapor. In an atmosphere model, stratiform cloud is that produced by large-scale convergence (not the convection schemes).

tntd.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Numerical Diffusion
tntd.comment: This includes any horizontal or vertical numerical temperature diffusion not associated with the parametrized moist physics or the resolved dynamics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be excluded, as should any diffusion which is included in the terms from the resolved dynamics.   This term is required to check the closure of the temperature budget.

tntmp27.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Model Physics
tntmp27.comment: Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget.

tntpbl.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Boundary Layer Mixing
tntpbl.comment: Includes all boundary layer terms including diffusive terms.

tntrl27.comment: Tendency of air temperature due to longwave radiative heating

tntrlcs.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Clear Sky Longwave Radiative Heating
tntrlcs.comment: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Clear Sky Longwave Radiative Heating

tntrs27.comment: Tendency of air temperature due to shortwave radiative heating

tntrscs.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Clear Sky Shortwave Radiative Heating
tntrscs.comment: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Clear Sky Shortwave Radiative Heating

tntscp.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Stratiform Clouds and Precipitation
tntscp.comment: The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. Air temperature is the bulk temperature of the air, not the surface (skin) temperature. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. A variable with the standard name tendency_of_air_temperature_due_to_stratiform_cloud_and_precipitation should contain net latent heating effects of all processes which convert stratiform clouds and precipitation between water vapour, liquid or ice phases. In an atmosphere model, stratiform cloud is that produced by large-scale convergence (not the convection schemes).

treeFracBdlDcd.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
treeFracBdlDcd.comment: This is the fraction of the entire grid cell  that is covered by broadleaf deciduous trees.

treeFracBdlEvg.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
treeFracBdlEvg.comment: This is the fraction of the entire grid cell  that is covered by broadleaf evergreen trees.

treeFracNdlDcd.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
treeFracNdlDcd.comment: This is the fraction of the entire grid cell  that is covered by needleleaf deciduous trees.

treeFracNdlEvg.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
treeFracNdlEvg.comment: This is the fraction of the entire grid cell  that is covered by needleleaf evergreen trees.

tslsiLut.comment: Surface temperature (i.e. temperature at which long-wave radiation emitted)

twap.comment: Product of air temperature and pressure tendency

ua.comment: 'Eastward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed eastward (negative westward). Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.)

ua27.comment: 'Eastward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed eastward (negative westward). Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.)

uqint.comment: Column integrated eastward wind times specific humidity

ut.comment: Product of air temperature and eastward wind

utendnogw.comment: Tendency of the eastward wind by parameterized nonorographic gravity waves.

utendogw.comment: Tendency of the eastward wind by parameterized orographic gravity waves.

va.comment: 'Northward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed northward (negative southward). Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.)

va27.comment: 'Northward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed northward (negative southward). Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector, with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.)

vegFrac.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
vegFrac.comment: fraction of grid cell that is covered by vegetation.This SHOULD be the sum of tree, grass, crop and shrub fractions.

vegHeight.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
vegHeight.comment: Height is the vertical distance above the surface. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy.

vegHeightCrop.cell_methods: area: time: mean where crops (comment: mask=cropFrac)
vegHeightCrop.long_name: Vegetation height averaged over the crop fraction of a grid cell.
vegHeightCrop.comment: Height is the vertical distance above the surface. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy.

vegHeightGrass.cell_methods: area: time: mean where natural_grasses (comment: mask=grassFrac)
vegHeightGrass.long_name: Vegetation height averaged over the grass fraction of a grid cell.
vegHeightGrass.comment: Height is the vertical distance above the surface. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy.

vegHeightPasture.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
vegHeightPasture.long_name: Vegetation height averaged over the pasture fraction of a grid cell.
vegHeightPasture.comment: Height is the vertical distance above the surface. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy.

vegHeightShrub.cell_methods: area: time: mean where shrubs (comment: mask=shrubFrac)
vegHeightShrub.long_name: Vegetation height averaged over the shrub fraction of a grid cell.
vegHeightShrub.comment: Height is the vertical distance above the surface. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy.

vegHeightTree.cell_methods: area: time: mean where trees (comment: mask=treeFrac)
vegHeightTree.long_name: Vegetation height averaged over the tree fraction of a grid cell.
vegHeightTree.comment: Height is the vertical distance above the surface. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy.

vqint.comment: Column integrated northward wind times specific humidity

vt.comment: Product of air temperature and northward wind

vtendnogw.comment: Tendency of the northward wind by parameterized nonorographic gravity waves.  (Note that CF name tables only have a general northward tendency for all gravity waves, and we need it separated by type.)

vtendogw.comment: Tendency of the northward wind by parameterized orographic gravity waves.  (Note that CF name tables only have a general northward tendency for all gravity waves, and we need it separated by type.)

wap.comment: Omega (vertical velocity in pressure coordinates, positive downwards)

wetlandCH4.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wetlandCH4.long_name: Grid averaged methane emissions from wetlands

wetlandCH4cons.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wetlandCH4cons.long_name: Grid averaged methane consuption (methanotrophy) from wetlands
wetlandCH4cons.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Downward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed downward (negative upward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The chemical formula for methane is CH4. The mass is the total mass of the molecules. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. Wetlands are areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year, including during the growing season. The precise conditions under which wetlands produce and consume methane can vary between models.

wetlandCH4prod.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wetlandCH4prod.long_name: Grid averaged methane production (methanogenesis) from wetlands
wetlandCH4prod.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The chemical formula for methane is CH4. The mass is the total mass of the molecules. The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. 'Emission' means emission from a primary source located anywhere within the atmosphere, including at the lower boundary (i.e. the surface of the earth). 'Emission' is a process entirely distinct from 're-emission' which is used in some standard names.

wetlandFrac.cell_methods: area: mean where land over all_area_types time: mean
wetlandFrac.long_name: Fraction of a grid cell covered by wetland.
wetlandFrac.comment: Report only one year if specified fraction is used, or time series if values are determined dynamically.

wtd.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
wtd.comment: Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. The water table is the surface below which the soil is saturated with water such that all pore spaces are filled.

xgwdparam.comment: Parameterised x-component of gravity wave drag

ygwdparam.comment: Parameterised y- component of gravity wave drag

zg27.comment: Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.
